Yes, gas companies argue "there is no evidence" of water contamination from fracking, but, if that's true, isn't it likely that there's "no evidence" only because we don't yet know enough?
Sometimes it takes decades to appreciate impacts of large-scale extraction activities. Take the example of hydraulic gold mining in the Northern California foothills in the latter half of the 1800s. It's my understanding that only recently have scientists been able to confirm that the very high concentrations of toxic mercury in San Francisco Bay fish is overwhelmingly due to the gold mining activities which took place in the foothills over a hundred years ago (when mercury was washed downstream with mining waste, ultimately settling in Bay sediment and getting into the food web).

Just because one fuel is "cleaner" (and this is quite debatable) than another doesn't mean it's good. It just means it's less bad. The key thing, which nobody wants to talk about, is to conserve. We could use so much less fuel than we do, and have much less need to produce it, but that would require sacrifice, and nobody wants to do that, especially Americans, the most spoiled people in history.

The more we wantonly rape the land, and consume resources, and dump toxins into the air and water, and proliferate, and generally upset the balance of nature, the more we ensure that at a certain point, most likely sooner rather than later, we will make the planet uninhabitable for ourselves. Anyone who doesn't see this is either terribly deluded, or simply looking for an excuse not to have to cut back their destructive modern lifestyle.

We don't "own" anything. It's all on loan from Nature. Nature is the one true god. Disrespect it, and be prepared to incur its wrath. The human race is in for it big time.

And I hope the changes fracking create in the geohydrology do not result in the fracking fluids poisoning the aquifer, because fracking occurs at many depths, some of them within the range of the aquifers we drink from.
And how far below the ground is the water you or anyone else drinks from? Aquifers can be quite deep, shallow or anything in between.

This is what happens in a country that respects and protects property rights, including mineral rights.

All of the neo-luddites arguing against fracking are just latching onto an environmental issue with any appreciation for how much cleaner natural gas is than coal or any idea how far down beneath the ground the drilling takes place.

Good for this lady, I hope she gets filthy rich.

Very disappointing.

I also attended the event at the African American Museum in Philadelphia at which Denise Dennis made a presentation about the Dennis Farm. The reporter’s condescending tone, i.e., “the natural gas industry has succeeded in persuading the owner of a historic Pennsylvania farm to allow gas to be extracted from beneath her property,” suggests that Ms. Dennis was hoodwinked into signing a lease agreement with Cabot Oil and Gas.

A graduate of Swarthmore College and author of three books, Ms. Dennis made it clear that she did extensive research about hydraulic fracturing and how the natural gas industry treats landowners. Based on her research, she made an informed decision that entering into a lease agreement would further the mission of the Dennis Farm Charitable Land Trust. Indeed, the signing bonus and royalties will be paid to the Land Trust.

Far from rolling over in his grave, Prince Perkins is probably saying, “You go, girl.” You found a way to tell our untold story and preserve this American treasure for another 220 years.

"Virtually certain that any of its harmful effects will be able to be eliminated by technology in 50 to 100 years"? I would love to know the source of your confidence.

The problem is twofold: (drastically) reducing the amount of CO2 (and more importantly, even more effective heat-trapping gases like methane) emitted by human activity, and sequestering some of the excessive amounts of greenhouse gases already in the atmosphere. I was under the impression that the latter task was nowhere near feasible, making the reduction of emissions all the more important. (And the reduction of emissions isn't going well enough.) I would truly love to hear that I'm missing some new and exciting developments.

Source of confidence. Generally, the very rapid and exponential expansion of science. See also Julian Simon.

Current specific ideas. Freeman Dyson: From
http://www.edge.org/3rd_culture/dysonf07/dysonf07_index.html

"To stop the carbon in the atmosphere from increasing, we only need to grow the biomass in the soil by a hundredth of an inch per year. Good topsoil contains about 10% biomass, so a hundredth of an inch of biomass growth means about a tenth of an inch of topsoil… If we use genetic engineering to put more biomass into roots, we can probably achieve much more rapid growth of topsoil. I conclude from this calculation that the problem of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is a problem of land management, not a problem of meteorology. ...."

Nathan Myrvold has proposed hoses attached to helium balloons 25 miles into the atmosphere to pump particles into the atmosphere to block the sun's rays. When you think that one volcanic eruption can affect the earth's climate for 2 years (Pinatubo), this isn't as crazy as it sounds at first blush.

In any event, my basic idea is that we will have unimaginably more knowledge in 50 years than we have now, and at that time, it should be quite easy to deal with a trace gas.

JD

Sounds like JD is promoting a stalling tatic rather than offering anything useful. Don't worry about the pollution we are emitting today...someone in the future will save us. Of course, most of us will be gone in 50 years and won't care. Hey, JD...that's your real point here, isn't it? You don't care what happens...so let someone in the future figure it out. And you say trace gas as if it was miniscule when it actually amounts to millions of tons.

As for Freeman Dyson...he says it himself:
"The moral of this story is clear. Even a smart twenty-two-year-old is not a reliable guide to the future of science. And the twenty-two-year-old has become even less reliable now that he is eighty-two."

Well, I can't argue with that statement. What level of arrogance develops in people who make their name in one field and now think they are experts on everything (eg. Shockley and eugenics)? Dyson states that the computer modelers have become too enamored with their models and can't think outside the box. The problem with that observation is the large number of scientists gathering data outside of computer models...that also provide evidence of climate change. So, Dyson is more at fault than the scientist's he criticises for only considering climate models.

Article should be titled the Ignorant Economist. CO2 is a trace gas (I know its effects are magnified), and it is virtually certain that any of its harmful effects will be able to be eliminated by technology in 50 to 100 years as technology increases exponentially. He is also apparently unaware of the third rate quality of institutional climate "research." (Check out Michael Mann's use of Tiljander statistics upside down. Also, check out the UEA's horrendous handling of climate data.)

JD
